newsitem.title: ITALY: Milan court seizes Brazil assets held by bank.
newsitem.headline: Milan court seizes Brazil assets held by bank.

text.p: A sequestration order has been served on the Milan branch of Germany's Deutsche Bank ordering the seizure of Brazilian assets including proceeds of a June 2 500 billion lire bond issue, a lawyer said on Monday.
The order by a Milan court, also served on Deutsche's investment banking offshoot Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, was issued on behalf of Swiss trading company Inter-Continental de Cafe.
The order was served on June 19, said Paolo Zambelli, a lawyer acting for Inter-Continental.

Inter-Continental is one of four trading companies seeking compensation from the Brazilian government after the now-defunct Brazilian Coffee Institute (IBC) failed to pay up after instructing them to purchase coffee on its behalf.
Zambelli said the legal basis for the sequestration order was a sentence by Britain's High Court in 1990 ordering the IBC to compensate the four companies.
The British court's ruling was later ratified by an appeals court in the Northeast Italian seaport of Trieste.

Deutsche Bank in Milan declined official comment, but a source there said the bank would not be required to disclose whether it is holding any Brazilian assets until the case comes to court next year.
Deutsche still planned to offer Brazilian bonds to its Italian clients, the source added. "We intend to continue with the sale of this product. It is going ahead."
